node.title: error: no member named 'set_hdf5_writing' in 'libMesh::ExodusII_IO'
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am trying to compile moose, version idaholab/next, but get the following error upon compile (from within tensor_mechanics module):
In file included from /Users/aruybalid/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/constraints_Unity.C:3:
/Users/aruybalid/projects/moose/framework/src/constraints/AutomaticMortarGeneration.C:728:32: error: no member named 'set_hdf5_writing' in 'libMesh::ExodusII_IO'
    mortar_segment_mesh_writer.set_hdf5_writing(false);

I have updated mamba (mamba update --all), and done make clobberall, before compile.
This seems to be a libmesh-related issue.
Any idea how I can resolve this to proceed?

solved over slack
mamba update had failed due to connection

node.title: Compute average value of Elements within a certain height range of mesh
node.bodyText:
Hello!
I have a question about computing average value of Elements within a certain height range of mesh.
For example, the mesh size I used for the simulation is 10 x 10 x 10 um^3.
I would like to compute the average value of Elements within the range of height from 0 to 1 um and export the value as output(*.CSV).
Is this possible?
If not, what would be the alternative?
Thank you for your help.
Best regards,
Hokon Kim

Hello
So the ElementValueSampler is definitely what you will want to use
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/ElementValueSampler.html
You could create a new block for the region of interest and block-restrict it
For example with this: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator.html
OR
you could just output it for the whole mesh and sort out the elements in the CSV file. There is even a sort_by parameter in the sampler, so you could sort the output by z then read only part of the file in your postprocessing workflow
Guillaume

Thanks for your reply.
I checked the first way you suggested. I got the point.
Specifically, what I want to compute is "one of Material Property values".
I don't think this Material Property can be dealt as Variables (or AuxVariables).
In ElementValueSampler, it looks like only Variable(AuxVariable) could be used.
Is there a way to copy Material Property into AuxVariable?

there is
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/MaterialRealAux.html

I really appreciate your help!
I would try this way, and let's see!

I have questions.
First of all, when I made a subdomain through ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator, subdomain requires Active Kernel.
I thought that subdomain restricted the interested domain including the information I assigned at the original blocks, but it didn't look like that.
Is there a way making a subdomain copying the information from the original block?
(with no requirement for Active Kernel, just used for computing the average value of Elements)
Also, when I tried ElementValueSampler, many csv files for each time step were exported.
Ultimately what I want to print out in csv file is "the single value representing the average value of Elements within a certain range of height" like below.
Voltage | Current | ........ | Avg. of K from 0 to 1 um | Avg. of K from 1 to 2 um | ... |
1.02   |   3.1      | ........ |                     2034            |                   1200               | ... |
If I use ElementValueSampler, is there a way not to generate other csv files and to print out the information into original csv file?

Hello
So you can turn off the requirement for an active kernel with this option
[Problem]
  kernel_coverage_check = false
[]

But it's better to just not block restrict the kernels and variables and let them execute everywhere in your case I think. That way the subdomain modifications wont affect the equations.
You can use this option contains_complete_history to merge all the csv files for each time step with the ElementValueSampler.
You cannot merge the postprocessors and the vectorpostprocessor output that easily. So this table you describe would only work if you use the subdomain methods and not the ElementValueSampler imo

Then, what about this combinations?
Several subdomains (by using ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator)

I will assign the needed parameters like the target Elemental value(Materials property)
Kernels will work on each subdomain similar to original blocks.

ElementAverageMaterialProperty

This postprocessor will work on each subdomain and give me the single value (average) and export the value in CSV.

I just attached the code and mesh for simple test. But after assigning parameters into subdomain, I cannot get the result.
TEST.zip

What app do I need to run this? Looks like you have some custom objects.
It seems you have added sub_0 to all the block restrictions in the system.
Can you add show_info = true to the ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator ? To see if it worked
Also what are you getting for the result currently?

Yes, I forgot that in my apps, there were several custom kernels and materials.
"show_info = true" in ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator gave me some information about the subdomain.
I just knew that the subdomain includes unnecessary blocks' information.
Currently, I use "combinatorial_geometry = 'z > 0 & z < 0.0002 & x > 1.89861e-5 & x < 0.0002 & y > 1.89939e-5 & y < 0.0002'"
However, what I want to do is a certain height range of one block ('PT_TPB_TET4'), but above rectangle includes a part of 4 block's information.
Is there a way to pick a certain block as subdomain? not the rectangle..
(e.g., z in 'PT_TPB_TET4' > 0 & z in 'PT_TPB_TET4' < 0.0002)
Lastly, if I add subdomain into the current input file, then it can be run, but it cannot converge.
(I think the subdomain has the part of information, specifically the subdomain is disconnected so it cannot converge)

Try adding the block = '... sub_0' in the GlobalParams. You're probably missing a block-restriction in one object.
I dont think we can do what you want with the mesh generators right now.
Try this:

place z in an auxvariable using a ParsedFunction and a FunctionAux
use the https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobject/CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier.html with z as the variable and the threshold and block-restrict it to PT_TPB_TET4. If you only want the final result, you can execute this on FINAL and not have to worry about block restriction of the kernels
use the ElementValueSampler with block-restriction on the new block

[Functions]
  [./testFunction]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 'z > 0 & z < 0.0002'
  [../]
[]

[UserObjects]
  [./just_test]
    type = CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier
    coupled_var = 'test_z'
    block = 'PT_TPB_TET4'
    threshold = 0
    subdomain_id = 100
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./test_z]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    block = 'PT_TPB_TET4'
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./a]
    type = FunctionAux
    variable = test_z
    function = testFunction
  [../]
[]

I don't get it how z can be used for specifying the interested height.
Also, I don't know how to adjust threshold and sub_domain_id in CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier.
I thought "sub_domain_id" is used to specify the new block I'm interested.
"Requested subdomain 100 does not exist" is the error message I got for now....
Does this new subdomain affect the original mesh ('PT_TPB_TET4')?

try this
[Functions]
  [.z_function]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 'z'
  [../]
[]

[UserObjects]
  [./just_test]
    type = CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier
    coupled_var = 'z_var'
    block = 'PT_TPB_TET4'
    threshold = 0.0002
    subdomain_id = 100
    execute_on = FINAL
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [z_var]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    block = 'PT_TPB_TET4'
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./a]
    type = FunctionAux
    variable = z_var
    function = z_function
  [../]
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [./TEST]
    type = ElementAverageMaterialProperty
    mat_prop = 'tpbActivity_S0'
    block = '100'
  [../]
[]

The codes you gave me worked.
I added the PP like above, but the error message "the following blocks (ids) do no exist on the mesh: 100" popped up.
I tried this, but it showed the same error as well.
[VectorPostprocessors]
  [./test]
    type = ElementValueSampler
    block = '100'
    sort_by = z
    variable = z_var
  [../]
[]

testcode.zip

when you look at the mesh does the subdomain appear?
Maybe I did not set the threshold right?
also the UserObject is executed on FINAL, so before that if you run anything on subdomain 100, it does not exist yet

First, in the block, there were only 4 blocks. subdomain didn't appear.
I ran the UserObject without applying execute_on.

then you need to check the parameters.
btw for the previous approach, there is a parameter to exclude some subdomains
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator.html
I didnt know about it

Currently, I'm still stuck.
Based on what you suggested, I will try to implement the function that I wanted.
For exclude some subdomain parameter, there is no way to specify the other blocks inside of subdomain as far as I know....

You specify the domains you exclude, not the domains you include.
Yup paraview confirms the user object did not add the block.
Can you execute the user object and the FunctionAux on INITIAL and TIMESTEP_BEGIN and see if it works then?
The z_var needs to be populated and the UO needs to be exceuted before other code referring to them is ran

node.title: Reduced Integration in MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Hello,
is there a way to find out how many quadrature points an element uses in MOOSE? For example ABAQUS has a documentation for each element where the nodes and the quadrature points are numbered respectively. Looking through the LibMesh documentation I only found a numbering for the nodes but not for the qps. Does that mean every element in MOOSE is fully integrated? Is there a way to manually switch to reduced integration?
I'm aware there is the volumetric_locking_correction feature but to my understanding that is not same thing. Or am I wrong here?

Elements are by default integrated via the exact quadrature rule. This can be changed from the quadrature executioner block.
The volumetric locking correction flag is recommended for mechanics problems and first order Lagrange elements.

If you set that flag, spatial numerical integration is automatically changed to remove volumetric locking and distinguish between deviatoric and volumetric parts. Which is a particular way to do selective integration.

Hello
You can set the quadrature block in the Executioner block as mentioned above, see this page:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/actions/SetupQuadratureAction.html
Guillaume

Can I ask a follow up question? What is the "order" (first, second, etc...) nomenclature mean in the Quadrature block?
For instance, if I have second-order (n=2) variables, and I want to integrate them fully, is the Quadrature order "second" to match the order of the polynomial? Or does it refer to the number of quadrature points?

so it's linked to the order of the polynomial (usually) basis the quadrature is obtained from.
For a second order variable, you have to multiply it by a second order test function on top so you end up with needing a 4th order quadrature to integrate it perfectly (well I m taking a lot of shortcuts here, depends on the quadrature).

Well let's assume Gauss quadrature for now. In Abaqus terminology, reduced integration means "elements use one fewer integration point in each direction", see here. In that link, the figure on the right is a 2D second-order "reduced" element with only 2 quadrature points in each dimension (4 total), as opposed to the typical "fully-integrated" element like that seen here with 3 quadrature points in each direction (9 total).
How would one implement the "reduced" element in MOOSE? I think the element type would be HEX8, variables would be second order Lagrange, and the quadrature order would be third? Would anything else change?

Would you want to reduce the order for an element or just for a side?
Either way the parameters to do this are here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/actions/SetupQuadratureAction.html
You dont need to downgrade the element type IMO, just the quadrature.
Whoops, I meant QUAD8 element, not HEX8. Sorry. Trying to reduce the quadrature inside the element. Basically just like the examples I linked to.

if it's for the whole element not just the side I think you ll need to define a block.
@recuero for correctness-check on this

Setting quadrature order to element order minus one is one way to do what you described. But that's not ideal in the multiphysics setting as moose doesn't allow different quadrature for different variables. Ideally you only want to do reduced integration for the mechanics problem, (if that abaqus page is what you are after) volumetric_locking_correction is the right parameter to set.

As @HuGary  @hugary1995 said, in a multiphysics run, the quadrature rule you choose in the executioner will apply to all variables in the element (per mesh block). You may get away with underintegrating in some multiphysics problems potentially, but I'd assume this will need to be assessed case by case. The particular modes of deformation of an element typically have a larger importance in mechanics problems with plasticity, e.g, compared to other physics.
I think the original question goes back to the fact that, to ensure correctness and optimal computational effort in solid mechanics finite element problems, reduced integration is typically used for higher order elements (for first order, we'd need hourglass controls, which we don't have yet). If you want to use higher order elements, I'd be hesitant to use the volumetric locking correction (maybe Gary has studied this more and can comment). Maybe it's worth playing with reduced integration with your problem. Based on Guillaume's description of libmesh's quadrature option, selecting THIRD and the blocks you want your quadrature to apply to will do the trick.

node.title: No mesh file was supplied and no generation block was provided
node.bodyText:
I was trying to self-define and solve an advection problem. Below is my input:
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh #Can generate simple lines, rectangles and rectangular prisms
  dim = 1
  nx = 100
  ny = 10
  xmax = 1
  ymax = 0.1
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Problem]
  type = FEProblem
  coord_type = RZ
  rz_coord_axis = X
[]

[Variables]
  [c]
    # Adds a linear Lagrange variable by default
  []
  [u]
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [advection]
    type = ConservativeAdvection
    variable = u
    velocity = '1 0 0'
    upwinding_type = full
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [./u_injection_left]
    type = InflowBC
    variable = u
    boundary = left
    velocity = '1 0 0'
    inlet_conc = 1
  [../]
  [./allow_mass_out]
    type = OutflowBC
    variable = u
    boundary = right
    value = '1 0 0'
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = NEWTON
  # Set PETSc parameters to optimize solver efficiency
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

After running, it gave me an error message:
No mesh file was supplied and no generation block was provided
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
Finished: Exit code: 1

I am confused since I did had the mesh block. Is there any wrong with my input?
Besides, if I would like to create a seperate mesh file, how should I do? Those .e file .msh file are produced manually or through some tools? Where can I find the guidance for this part?
Thank you so much for any help.

I am confused since I did had the mesh block. Is there any wrong with my input?

There is not necessarily a single object in the [Mesh] block, therefore you must provide it as such:
[Mesh]
  [gm] # any name you want here
    type = GeneratedMesh #Can generate simple lines, rectangles and rectangular prisms
    dim = 1
    nx = 100
    ny = 10
    xmax = 1
    ymax = 0.1
  []

  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]


Besides, if I would like to create a seperate mesh file, how should I do? Those .e file .msh file are produced manually or through some tools? Where can I find the guidance for this part?

We have many methods for generating a variety of common meshes. See the Mesh system (more importantly, the MeshGenerator objects) here: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Mesh/index.html
If you have a specific mesh in mind that you're trying to generate, we can try to point you in the right direction.

Thank you so much for your reply.
I tried to add an object name in Mesh block, but i seems that the message indicated the mesh problem still there:
No mesh file was supplied and no generation block was provided
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
Finished: Exit code: 1

I used the command to output the mesh '--mesh-only':
(moose) dff@dff-ThinkPad-T440:~/projects/redox/problems$ ../redox-opt -i Redox1.i --mesh-only mesh_file.e and there were some errors:
*** ERROR ***
Task add_mesh_generator is not registered to build MooseMesh derived objects

Stack frames: 14
0: libMesh::print_trace(std::ostream&)
1: moose::internal::mooseErrorRaw(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >)
2: ActionWarehouse::addActionBlock(std::shared_ptr<Action>)
3: Parser::walkRaw(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, hit::Node*)
4: Parser::walk(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, hit::Node*)
5: hit::Node::walk(hit::Walker*, hit::NodeType, hit::TraversalOrder)
6: hit::Node::walk(hit::Walker*, hit::NodeType, hit::TraversalOrder)
7: hit::Node::walk(hit::Walker*, hit::NodeType, hit::TraversalOrder)
8: Parser::parse(std::vector<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, std::allocator<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > > > const&)
9: MooseApp::setupOptions()
10: MooseApp::run()
11: ../redox-opt(+0x3163) [0x55a73855f163]
12: __libc_start_main
13: ../redox-opt(+0x33ea) [0x55a73855f3ea]
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
[unset]: write_line error; fd=-1 buf=:cmd=abort exitcode=1
:
system msg for write_line failure : Bad file descriptor

I am confused since my mesh information is just a very simple one. Attached was all my input:
[Mesh]
  [gm]
    type = GeneratedMesh #Can generate simple lines, rectangles and rectangular prisms
    dim = 2
    nx = 100
    ny = 10
    xmax = 1
    ymax = 0.1
  [] 
  
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Problem]
  type = FEProblem
  coord_type = RZ
  rz_coord_axis = X
[]

[Variables]
  [c]
    # Adds a linear Lagrange variable by default
  []
  [u]
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [advection]
    type = ConservativeAdvection
    variable = u
    velocity = '1 0 0'
    upwinding_type = full
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [./u_injection_left]
    type = InflowBC
    variable = u
    boundary = left
    velocity = '1 0 0'
    inlet_conc = 1
  [../]
  [./allow_mass_out]
    type = OutflowBC
    variable = u
    boundary = right
    value = '1 0 0'
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = NEWTON
  # Set PETSc parameters to optimize solver efficiency
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

replace GeneratedMesh with GeneratedMeshGenerator
see the docs here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/GeneratedMeshGenerator.html

Thank you so much for your help.
I used peacock to run my input and everything worked well. But there is another problem. When I tried to create a seperated mesh file using the command
(moose) dff@dff-ThinkPad-T440:~/projects/redox/problems$ ../redox-opt -i Redox1.i --mesh-only mesh_file.e , there were some errors:
*** ERROR ***
A 'InflowBC' is not a registered object.

If you are trying to find this object in a dynamically linked library, make sure that
the library can be found either in your "Problem/library_path" parameter or in the
MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable.

Stack frames: 21
0: libMesh::print_trace(std::ostream&)
1: moose::internal::mooseErrorRaw(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >)
2: void mooseError<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > >(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >&&)

4: Factory::getValidParams(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)
5: MooseObjectAction::MooseObjectAction(InputParameters)
6: AddBCAction::AddBCAction(InputParameters)
7: /home/dff/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so.0(+0x11ae698) [0x7f58a9cd3698]
8: /home/dff/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so.0(+0x11ae72a) [0x7f58a9cd372a]
9: ActionFactory::create(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, InputParameters&)
10: Parser::walkRaw(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, hit::Node*)
11: Parser::walk(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, hit::Node*)
12: hit::Node::walk(hit::Walker*, hit::NodeType, hit::TraversalOrder)
13: hit::Node::walk(hit::Walker*, hit::NodeType, hit::TraversalOrder)
14: hit::Node::walk(hit::Walker*, hit::NodeType, hit::TraversalOrder)
15: Parser::parse(std::vector<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, std::allocator<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > > > const&)
16: MooseApp::setupOptions()
17: MooseApp::run()
18: ../redox-opt(+0x3163) [0x5574e648e163]

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
[unset]: write_line error; fd=-1 buf=:cmd=abort exitcode=1
:
system msg for write_line failure : Bad file descriptor

I copied the relevant "InflowBC.c" and "InflowBC.h" files from the test tutorial and compiled it. I can use peacock to run my input so I think the compile process should work well. I uesed the same input but the process to create seperated mesh file failed. I am kind of consused. Is that because the --mesh-only  source code need to be revised for registerd object?

I m not sure.
In InflowBC.C can you can register("mooseTestApp" ... to register("MooseApp", ..
and try again?
also it shoud be InflowBC.C (capital C) btw
also if you are just generating a mesh file you can just comment out the boundary conditions. they are not part of the mesh

I created mesh file by only using mesh block. Thank you so much for your advice.
Besides, what is the difference between GeneratedMesh and GeneratedMeshGenerator? I am kind of confused since I thought my mesh is simple enough and those two should both work well.

GeneratedMesh was what we used before the mesh generators existed. Now we use the mesh generators, such as GeneratedMeshGenerator.
It was just a different system, still here due to slow deprecation of things to keep some amount of backwards compatibility
Thank you so much for your information.

node.title: Download and build rtags when install Atom
node.bodyText:
As recommended, I intalled Atom as my editor. I used the following command in building rtags
git clone https://github.com/Andersbakken/rtags.git
cd rtags/
git submodule init
git submodule update
mkdir mybuild && cd mybuild
cmake ..
make -j 24
sudo make install
It gave me some errors when I was trying to run 'cmake ..'. The messages looked like below:
-- The CXX compiler identification is unknown
CMake Error at CMakeLists.txt:2 (project):
No CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER could be found.
Tell CMake where to find the compiler by setting either the environment
variable "CXX" or the CMake cache entry CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER to the full path
to the compiler, or to the compiler name if it is in the PATH.
-- Configuring incomplete, errors occurred!
See also "/home/dff/rtags/mybuild/CMakeFiles/CMakeOutput.log".
See also "/home/dff/rtags/mybuild/CMakeFiles/CMakeError.log".

Hello
Did you try doing what it says? What does echo $CXX return?
In the moose mamba environment, CXX should be set already
Guillaume

Thank you so much for your reply. I didn't notice that the activation would become a problem. I activated moose in mamba environment, but It still didn't work.
The new error information was below:
-- The C compiler identification is GNU 9.4.0
-- The CXX compiler identification is GNU 9.3.0
-- Detecting C compiler ABI info
-- Detecting C compiler ABI info - done
-- Check for working C compiler: /usr/bin/cc - skipped
-- Detecting C compile features
-- Detecting C compile features - done
-- Detecting CXX compiler ABI info
-- Detecting CXX compiler ABI info - done
-- Check for working CXX compiler: /home/dff/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/mpicxx - skipped
-- Detecting CXX compile features
-- Detecting CXX compile features - done
CMake Error at cmake/FindLibClang.cmake:76 (message):
Could NOT find llvm-config executable and LIBCLANG_CXXFLAGS is not set
Call Stack (most recent call first):
src/CMakeLists.txt:81 (find_package)
-- Configuring incomplete, errors occurred!
See also "/home/dff/rtags/mybuild/CMakeFiles/CMakeOutput.log".
See also "/home/dff/rtags/mybuild/CMakeFiles/CMakeError.log".
Besides, when I run "echo $CXX", I got "mpicxx" under mamba environment.

CXX being mpicxx is correct
-- The C compiler identification is GNU 9.4.0
-- The CXX compiler identification is GNU 9.3.0

this is a problem. Should definitely be the same. The environment is either not installed well or something from your system is on your $PATH before the mamba compilers
I tried the "cmake" command before I activated moose. Is this the reason causing the difference? Or should I just update something?

This is the problem
-- Check for working C compiler: /usr/bin/cc - skipped

set CC to be mpicc export CC=mpicc then try again please

Thank you so much.
I tried the command -- Check for working C compiler: /usr/bin/cc - skipped and the message was:
--: command not found
I run the command in the directory '~/rtags/mybuild'.

This is not a command. This is part of the log you posted.
The command to run is this:
export CC=mpicc

Sorry about that. I misunderstood your meaning. I tried the command export CC=mpicc and cmake again but it seemed that the error was still there.

Could NOT find llvm-config executable and LIBCLANG_CXXFLAGS is not set

`

Could you please edit your message so we have the entire log?
Do you still have -- The CXX compiler identification is unknown  ?
Is your moose environment active when you are doing this?

Yes. I activated moose. This is a copied of the whole message:
(moose) dff@dff-ThinkPad-T440:~/rtags/mybuild$ export CC=mpicc
(moose) dff@dff-ThinkPad-T440:~/rtags/mybuild$ cmake ..

node.title: Divergence of divergence of a tensor

node.bodyText: You need third order spatial derivatives according to the equations you showed. So you can't really avoid using C1 function space. Hermite polynomials is one choice.

Correction: you could still use C0 functions if you use a split formulation, i.e. define some dummy variables to reduce the regularity of the stress divergence term, similar to the split cahn Hilliard equations.

Hey Gary, thanks for the prompt reply.
Yep I was thinking of doing the split as for Cahn-Hilliard equations (strategy that I use already on a chemical potential as I'm doing Cahn-Hilliard for another part of the equation). My main concern is how to replace _grad_u[_qp] by the divergence of a tensor.
I wrote down some equations to explain:
Noted, thanks! I'll try take it from there.

node.title: Error in using MultiAppCopyTransfer
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE Experts,
I am trying to transfer the data from sub_app (DIM_sub_particle) to main_app (test_2d) using following
[MultiApps]
  [full_solve]
    type = FullSolveMultiApp
    execute_on = initial
    positions = '0 0 0'
    input_files = DIM_sub_particle.i
    clone_master_mesh = true
  []
[]

[Transfers]
[./from_eta_gb]
    type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    source_variable = eta_gb
    variable = eta_gb
    from_multi_app = 'DIM_sub_particle'
  [../]
    [./from_eta_pmi]
    type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    source_variable = eta_pmi
    variable = eta_pmi
    from_multi_app = 'DIM_sub_particle'
  [../]
[]

However, I am getting the following error
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 1

*** ERROR ***
Unable to locate object: DIM_sub_particle.

DIM_sub_particle file is there in the same folder. I was using it earlier with older syntax but new syntax its not working.
Please let me know if I am doing it right and suggest some solutions.
Best
Avtar

Hello
The name of the sub app is full_solve not DIM_sub_particle
You just need to change that in to/from_multiapp in the transfers.
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud
Thank you very much. Its working now.
Best
Avtar

node.title: Converting a non-ADmaterial to an ADmaterial
node.bodyText:
Hello Dear Moose Developers
I recently have inroduced to this amazing framework nd I'm researching on soil mechanics. I've noticed that there are a lot of plasticity models available in Moose but so many of them do not support the AD properties. Is there anyway to convert those plasticity models into AD? if yes, where can I start? what do I have to change? I wanted to use the crystal plasticity model but since my kernels are all AD and my displacements are coupled with phasefield and pressure and temperature it is impossible for me to use the non AD kernels or materials
Best,
Mahyar

Hello
You can combine AD kernels with non AD kernels, that is not an issue. AD materials and non-AD materials are harder to mix, but you can use this object
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/MaterialADConverter.html
to create the non AD versions.
One thing to be careful about though, is that the derivatives may not have been defined in the AD version of a material since they are automatically calculated. In this case, you will have to redefine them yourself.
Guillaume

Thank you for your answer, I'm trying to implement stress divergence which is multiplied by phasefield variable. My phasefield variable is AD variable, but I want to use crystal plasticity which is a non-AD material. So the kernel will be multiplication of a AD variable to a non-AD variable is that ok? Also, there are no examples on how to use the ADMaterialConverter. I completely new to this framework and really dont know how to use this function to convert material type.
Best,

There's not really such a thing as an AD variable. AD quantities are quantities that carry their derivative with regards to the nonlinear variables along with them.
Multiplying AD and non AD quantities is OK as long as:

numerically, it turns out not to matter to be missing some Jacobian terms.
OR
you make sure the contribution to the Jacobian is correct by implementing the computeQpJacobian routine yourself. This is disabled for ADKernels though. Implementing this could be just as much work as implementing an AD plasticity model.
What kernel are you using? Which plasticity model are you using?

Here's an example of the materialADConverter.
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/8b86c661f83d7d0d6bfd97f78e949e6228c86d3c/test/tests/materials/ad_material/conversion/1d_dirichlet.i

Thank you for your answer, my kernel is an AD kernel written by myself for calculating the multi-phase linear momentum equation. It has three different stress divergence in it with three different base name. For the stress with the base name "ice" im trying to use the crystal plasticity model which is not an AD model.
The problem is my linear momentum equation is coupled with phase-filed variable which is also an AD quantity. As far as I understood, when I have a AD kernel with all AD material properties, it is impossbile to use a non-AD material in between with a Newton solver that im using.
fortunately you mentioned that I can still use a non-AD material and get it to work. I tried to change the material property to a non AD for the ice stress but for some reason crystal plasticity is not accepting the deformation gradients from the ComputeFiniteStrain (I asked this question in another thread). I dont think I can use the tensor mechaincs master class action since it just adds an stress divergence but my stress is multiplied by a phasefield variable which makes it impossible to use master class.
Also I've tried to use the materialADConverter, but it gives me error that this object is not a registered object?? not sure what is this....

Thank you for your answer, my kernel is an AD kernel written by myself for calculating the multi-phase linear momentum equation. It has three different stress divergence in it with three different base name. For the stress with the base name "ice" im trying to use the crystal plasticity model which is not an AD model.

Ok an ADKernel will not let you write in the derivatives manually (well it could but we dont recommend doing it the way it could).
So you can either:

work with converted AD properties (converted to AD using the converter, but missing the derivatives) and miss the derivative terms
convert the crystal plasticity model. Which one is that? What is the object name?


The problem is my linear momentum equation is coupled with phase-filed variable which is also an AD quantity. As far as I understood, when I have a AD kernel with all AD material properties, it is impossbile to use a non-AD material in between with a Newton solver that im using.

It is not impossible. It is just that using regular properties will miss some derivatives, so the Jacobian in the Newton method will not be numerically perfect.

fortunately you mentioned that I can still use a non-AD material and get it to work. I tried to change the material property to a non AD for the ice stress but for some reason crystal plasticity is not accepting the deformation gradients from the ComputeFiniteStrain (I asked this question in another thread). I dont think I can use the tensor mechaincs master class action since it just adds an stress divergence but my stress is multiplied by a phasefield variable which makes it impossible to use master class.

Ok makes sense why you cannot use the action.

Also I've tried to use the materialADConverter, but it gives me error that this object is not a registered object?? not sure what is this....

can you paste it here? It must be mispelled. This is available in every moose that is less than 6 months old

can you paste it here? It must be mispelled. This is available in every moose that is less than 6 months old

I noticed my version is old, I added the specific code and compiled and it works.


work with converted AD properties (converted to AD using the converter, but missing the derivatives) and miss the derivative terms
convert the crystal plasticity model. Which one is that? What is the object name?

I have tried it with converter and it's not converging, I think it's too nonlinear and if not provided with derivative it cannot converge.
I am using the CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate within ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress. I would assume the last solution is to write an AD material property for it but I really have no idea how to start the whole code is very overwhelming and hard to digest for me since i'm both new to framework and C++ . If you had any guidlines on how I can write an AD material code for plasticity and updating the stress it would be really helpful.
Best,
Mahyar

so to converge a kernel or a material property to AD, in a quick way, not for general use in the framework, just copy paste the file with a different name and replace all instances of Real with ADReal.
If you want to contribute to the framework, you ll have to make a template on the AD type. We can help you with that too

node.title: how to add damping term to a scalar wave equation
node.bodyText:
Hi
I have a scalar wave equation where I need to add a damping term to it. The equation is as follows:

where u, is the scalar-valued function (the main variable). μ, η are the shear modulus and damping coefficient; respectively.
So, essentially it is diffusion term+damping term+ inertial term.
I could model the undamped system in the form:

But now, I am not sure how to add the damping term!
Any ideas on how to model this?

Hello
Is this because you want to model additional physical damping? Or because you want to numerically damp your equations? If the latter, you could try these objects:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Dampers/index.html
To get started on physical damping, I would do an integration by parts to remove the outer divergence term. Then you will be using the  gradSlnDot() function on the variable or preferably the coupledGradientDot(<variable_name>) from the Coupleable interface, to declare that term in the constructor of the object. Please let us know if you need help with that.
Guillaume

Hello
Is this because you want to model additional physical damping? Or because you want to numerically damp your equations? If the latter, you could try these objects: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Dampers/index.html
To get started on physical damping, I would do an integration by parts to remove the outer divergence term. Then you will be using the gradSlnDot() function on the variable or preferably the coupledGradientDot(<variable_name>) from the Coupleable interface, to declare that term in the constructor of the object. Please let us know if you need help with that.
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud , Yes, I am trying to add physical damping. Yes, please, I really appreciate your help.
You are trying to merge the damping and the diffusion kernels right? Like use one kernel for both terms in the equation?

Either way is OK. It's preferred to have a separate kernel if you foresee having to turn it on/off for debugging / prototyping for example.
Does it compile now?
Where did you find this btw?
  if (_static_initialization && _t == _dt)

if start_time is below 0 that may never trigger for example.

Either way is OK. It's preferred to have a separate kernel if you foresee having to turn it on/off for debugging / prototyping for example.
Does it compile now?

I am still trying to figure out how to implement the computeQpJacobian(), computeQpOffDiagJacobian(unsigned int jvar) and computeQpCJacobian()

Where did you find this btw?
  if (_static_initialization && _t == _dt)


I borrowed it from DynamicStressDivergenceTensors.C in the definition of the computeQpResidual()

if start_time is below 0 that may never trigger for example.

I was thinking that way because I wanted something to switch on/off the damping term in the diffusion kernel.

Once you have implemented that you can use the jacobian analyzer to make sure it's correct
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/help/development/analyze_jacobian.html
I'd use a boolean parameter to turn it on/off (if keeping in the same kernel).

I think the idea here is if the diffused variable is NOT the variable of the equation.
Say you are solving for variable c and have a variable d in your equation
laplacian c + laplacian(d) + dc/dt = 0
then you use the coupled variable feature, and you have an off-diagonal term since the 'diagonal' is by definition terms for the same variable as the equation

node.title: Disabling print on Console
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I have been working on this code and have gotten to the point where everything works.
Thus, is there a way to disable printing ability on console? I have disabled the residual but still prints the timesteps, time, steady-state norm. I still would like to save the output at the end step.
Thank you!
[Debug]
show_var_residual_norms = false
[]

[Executioner]
type = Transient
automatic_scaling = true
end_time = 1.0e-3
solve_type = 'LINEAR'
dtmin = 1.0e-20
dtmax = 1.0e-6
steady_state_detection = true
steady_state_tolerance = 1e-30
nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-50
[TimeStepper]
type = IterationAdaptiveDT
growth_factor = 1.005
dt = 1.0e-12
[]
[]

[Preconditioning]
[smp]
type = SMP
full = true
[]
[]

[Outputs]
[hope_this_works]
type = Console
outlier_variable_norms = false
execute_scalars_on = none
clear_after_output = true
[]
[out]
type = CSV
execute_on = 'FINAL'
show = '{species}'
[]
[]

Hello
You're on the right track with the [hope_this_works] console block. You should just execute it on FINAL or on TIMESTEP_END.
Note that you can disable a lot of printing with these 3 options in [Outputs]:
  print_linear_converged_reason = false
  print_linear_residuals = false
  print_nonlinear_converged_reason = false

Guillaume
Thank you very much. I have them in my [hope_this_works] block. I have managed to remove some stuff on console. Is there a way to hide or not print time steps, time, dt or solve convergence?
Not that I know of currently. There's planned changes in the future for setting a verbosity level, we'll make sure to have options to hit all these.
Thank you very much!
